title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
Hundreds of companies that went public when the IPO market was booming have suffered such sharp reversals that they now face the prospect that their shares may never recover.

---

The Bank of Japan decided to let a benchmark interest rate rise to 0.5% from 0.25%, pushing up the yen and ending a stretch in which the BOJ was the only major central bank not to raise rates.

---

Epic Games agreed to pay $520 million to resolve FTC allegations that it violated privacy protections for children and tricked players into making unintended purchases.

---

The EU charged Facebook parent Meta with antitrust violations for allegedly distorting competition by tying its online classified-ad service to its social network.

---

Twitter faced new uncertainty after a majority of respondents voted for Musk to step down as chief executive in an online poll.

---

Major U.S. stock indexes fell, with the S&P 500, Nasdaq and Dow losing 0.9%, 1.5% and 0.5%, respectively.

---

The U.S. arm of Binance agreed to acquire the assets of bankrupt crypto lender Voyager Digital.

---

The Biden administration delayed proposing detailed rules for new tax incentives for electric vehicles, following pushback from European and Asian allies.

---

Honeywell International will pay nearly $203 million to resolve bribery investigations in the U.S. and Brazil, the company said.
